text:
Instructions for *NodeSdkSample* app have a step:
“Modify /etc/hosts file by appending a new alias entry tlsca: 
sudo vi /etc/hosts
127.0.0.1    localhost          tlsca”

Is this done to satisfy requirements of *SSL Hostname Verification* routine?
Is this something controlled by “*serverhostoverride*” entry of the *core.yaml*  file?

`Is this done to satisfy requirements of *SSL Hostname Verification* routine?`   Yes
`Is this something controlled by “*serverhostoverride*” entry of the *core.yaml*  file?`  No - this is used by the peer acting as client
if you want to do things correctly, you should generate certificates where the CN and/or SANs have valid hostnames

<@U0PB67X4K> 
If i understand correctly, *by default* memberservice generates *tls certificate* where "*tlsca*" is used as a *default CN and/or SAN*. 
Am i Correct ? 
That's why hosts file override/aliasing is necessary.
that's correct but that's not how one would actually run things in real life

<@U2MLMERFD|mrbuggy> uploaded a file: <https://hyperledgerproject.slack.com/files/mrbuggy/F2W02UCG6/-.txt|Untitled> and commented: Hi all, does anyone know why I'm getting these errors when I try to do chain.register(), chain.enroll() separetely instead of the default chain.registerAndEnroll() like how it is done in  app.js of the fabric starter kit?

initial_comment.comment: Hi all, does anyone know why I'm getting these errors when I try to do chain.register(), chain.enroll() separetely instead of the default chain.registerAndEnroll() like how it is done in  app.js of the fabric starter kit?
